title: My sister is filing bankruptcy, and has been paying me back for money she borrowed. Can the courts take my money?
question: My sister borrowed $20,000.00 from me and is now going to file for bankruptcy. She said that if she can show that she hasn't been paying me for a year, that the courts will dismiss the loan. But if I keep records that she has been paying me, that the courts will take that money from me. How can this be??? I didn't do anything wrong, and I'm just trying to collect the money she borrowed from me!
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Credit,Debt,Debt relief,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt
answers: Yikes. Be careful. How much money has she repaid back to you over the past year? That will make a huge difference. You're right you did nothing wrong but unfortunately the BK Code has that rule about "insider payments" and so the belief there is that ALL creditors should be treated equally the same. My advice is to make sure she talks with her attorney about the specifics of her case and how it may impact you. She can always, once the debt is Discharged, pay you back voluntarily and so my main concern would be whether the Trustee will demand of you to give back whatever amounts she's paid to you over the past year.

I agree with the previous answers. It may feel like you are being punished for simply trying to help your sister, but unfortunately there is a very specific law designed for your sister's particular situation. People that are filing bankruptcy are usually in financial distress. However, sometimes those people feel like a certain credit card or doctor or family member has been especially good to them and they want ot repay those specific debts. Unfortunately, while that may seem like an innocent enough idea, what is happening in the eyes of the bankruptcy court is that this person intending to file for bankruptcy is paying off some debts while leaving other creditors with less potential property to recover their debts from. Bankruptcy is supposed to be an orderly process, and when the debtor tries to pay off some creditors, they perform something called a "preference." Your sister may be a bit confused about this. She has to disclose any payments she made to you within 1 year before filing. If they were regular monthly payments and she still has money she owes you that may be a good defense. Like the other attorneys pointed out, the safest thing to do is to wait 1 year from when she last made a payment to you. However, if that is not an option, you can attempt to return the money to your sister and have her attorney exempt the money and once your sister gets her discharge, she will be able to do with funds as she pleases. At that point she can return the money to you. Hope this helps.

Attorney Curl's answer is absolutely correct. Bankruptcy code section 547 authorizes a trustee to avoid preferential transfers including those to insiders such as family members. The theory or policy behind this is that why should XYZ bank be left holding the bag on the money they lent, but yet sister WAS paid.

Bankruptcy law requires full and complete disclosure, or section 727 can deny a discharge. So, sister has to disclose this. I think the best suggestion is to wait for a year after the last payment.

Finally, after sister gets the discharge, if she does gat a chapter 7 discharge, most or all of her unsecured debt is gone. However, no law prohibits her from paying you if she so chooses. People often do this with a trusted family doctor or dentist.

I truly wish you the best.

Payments by a debtor to a family member, business associate or persons of a close relationship (called "insiders") are potential problems. Payments to a family member is called a preference, because the payments were made to creditors you may have preferred over another. Since it's a family member, it's an "insider preference." It is possible for a trustee to "avoid" and recover those payments from a family member that received the payments if they were made within one year of your sister filing.

Your sister should work with her attorney to see if she can simply delay filing long enough so that there are no insider preferential payments at the time of filing. Perhaps the amounts at issue are so small the risk is low. Sometimes a family member can actually reloan the money to the debtor to prevent the trustee from trying to recover the money. This is something that your sister should consult with her counsel about to work toward a possible solution. Good luck.
